Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2015 10:32AM - edited Oct 15, 2015 10:41AM by leggo Mary625, I'm not sure if you were asking me or not, but I'll give my two cents. To me, and again, Jmho, mega-dosing would be taking anything over what is required to have levels in the normal range. Very subjective but if you're getting at least 15-20 minutes of midday sun with most of your skin exposed (no sunscreen wearing shorts and a tank, for instance) and are otherwise healthy, I think swallowing extra would be mega-dosing. All kinds of variables though, like skin color, age, geographic location etc. are a consideration. I would definitely supplement in the winter, but like someone else mentioned above, no where near some of the doses I've read on these boards on occasion. Having said that, I have substantial bone mets and I'm trying really hard not to have my kidney fail. Too much, I would think, but not really sure (just my opinion), would have a detrimental effect on the kidneys because of the hypercalcimia that comes with those mets. I suppose maybe that's why the required amounts are all over the place....skin color, age, location, and most importantly, overall health. That last one being the biggest factor of what's good for some not being good for everyone. It really shouldn't be complicated, but because of all these variables in how it is absorbed and metabolized, D is the one that can't be a "one size fits all". Jo-5, I think summed it up best. "normal is normal", which is different for everyone. D is kind of unique.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2014 02:16PM - edited Dec 3, 2014 02:20PM by leggo Bhd1, I'll address the question. Some might consider "doing great", stability of their cancer or no evidence of disease. It's really all relative. As my onc explained, just because we don't see it on imaging doesn't mean there isn't something there. I think too often we take that good news from a scan of a moment in time and consider ourselves cancer-free when it isn't the case. So often he has seen scans done, radiologist reports no concerns and then a month later all hell breaks loose. Also,  interpretation of the scan results plays into it. One sees one thing,  another sees something else. I know this from experience as well. Had headaches, dizzy, nausea so I had a brain mri. Nothing seen. Five weeks later I found out I had brain mets.  Also, our bodies have been poisoned by treatments. The toll that takes on say, your kidneys and liver is horrendous. Just because a scan shows no cancer, doesn't mean the organ isn't destroyed.  I've often wondered how many die from actual tumors, as opposed to organs shutting down because they can't handle anymore abuse. I suspect it's a lot.....and that can happen in a blink of an eye.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2015 05:16PM - edited Oct 14, 2015 05:27PM by leggo I'm not 100% sure (but about 90% sure) but I think the 25-hydroxy vitamin d is the important one. A level of 20 to 50 nanograms/ml. is the adequate range. I've been told it can be as low as 12 and still be normal if you're getting adequate sunlight, though I think that's probably a tad low for someone with cancer. My doctor also agrees with Jo-5. Mega dosing is a really bad idea. This is just my own opinion, but I would not supplement with a 26.3 25-hydroxy reading, but everyone's opinon probably differs, as do the opinions of doctors' probably. Eta: I'm basing this on someone who's blood calcium levels are in the normal range (i.e. no bone mets). That's where it would get a little trickier. Still trying to figure that one out.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 10:12AM leggo wrote: I'd like to preface this post by saying I am in no way minimizing anyone's experience or thoughts on LE. I just wanted to add my  experience a couple of years ago in which the radiologist made several attempts to inject dye into my "good arm", only because I told him to use that arm. He asked why after the failed attempts and I explained about having to baby the bad arm and he advised me that all the doctors and radiologists he works with or has been in contact with are re-thinking the whole thing. Apparantly there is no evidence to show that getting injections, iv's, cuts, etc. is actually the culprit of LE....more likely a cause they cannot identify at this point. After careful consideration, I tend to agree. I accidentally cut my arm that had 26 lymph nodes removed about five years ago and needed stitches. I fully expected to have problems, but they never came. I garden without gloves and have had numerous cuts, scratches, etc and decided that I would "let things happen" to my protected arm, because after numerous chemos, injections, etc. on my good arm, the veins are shot. The last 5 iv's and injections (for the last two years) have all been on my bad side and so far so good. I have noticed on occasion, that my arm is a little swollen. To counter-act the swelling, I find that a good rowing work-out reduces the swelling.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2014 01:59AM - edited Jul 4, 2014 02:02AM by leggo I suppose it all depends on who you talk to and how those people define "effective". For instance, if I went through chemo only to find out it didn't shrunk my tumor, spread or recurred shortly after, then I would agree with the graphic. If it worked to keep me cancer-free for years, then I would disagree. Even just reading people's stories on this site, you run the gammit of who has had success and who hasn't.  It's fairly easy for me to rationalize, but I see things in rather black/white, right/wrong. Recurrence or metastases shortly after chemo at a lesser stage, to me, translates to ineffective. Also, personally speaking from a Stage IV perspective, if it gives me an extra three, four months, leaving me disabled and damaged, it's grossly ineffective. Sadly, I can't think of a word that fits better than "grossly" without getting kicked off, but you get the idea.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2014 01:30PM - edited Nov 15, 2014 01:33PM by leggo Hi Threefilets. Unfortunately there's nothing anyone can do to "make" family members care. They are what they are. I don't know what country your in, but in Canada, being Stage IV, depending on the extent of your disease, you should be entitled to Home Care if you are unable to take care of yourself. You're cancer clinic's social worker should be able to assist you. Meals on Wheels and such programs are provided at a reduced rate. Even if you're not in Canada, I imagine that a clinical social worker could point you in the right direction to get the care you need. I'd start there. I'm so sorry your family is making this harder for you.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2014 08:47AM - edited Dec 13, 2014 08:52AM by leggo Btw, you can do a quick test on your own to figure out if your electrolytes are out of whack. As someone mentioned, it can cause all-over body pain. If the Epsom salts helped, you know you need more magnesium. If you chew a couple TUMS, and it improves, you need more calcium. If you drink a couple glasses of orange juice with improvement, you need more potassium. My first step would be to do all three and see if you get some relief. Just a little trick I learned while going through plasma exchange, without having to run to the doctor all the time. A little boost of each, if you're low on any, make a difference you should notice right away.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 08:01AM - edited Mar 24, 2014 08:06AM by leggo It's a completely personal decision. Some will insist it's medically necessary. I have been through six chemos and four years of herceptin and have never had a port or any trouble with my veins. The only difficulty I had was the dye for a CT scan, which went interstital and caused me a lot of grief and from what I've been told ports can't be used for that anyway. It was later determined that it was due to the tech's incompetence. I chose not to get a port because I really didn't want to look like, or be constantly reminded of the fact that I'm a cancer patient. It's probably best to get ALL your options from your medical team. Neither way is without it's risk of complications.....and it certainly has a lot to do with how competent your IV administrator is. Good luck to you, whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2015 12:31PM leggo wrote: They're both valid. Potatoes (fried), heated beyond 120C forms acrylamide, which is a toxic carcinogen. Anything fried in canola, soybean, safflower, corn, and other seed and nut oils will do the same, not just potatoes. You've probably heard about the potato thing in particular because people want crispy fries and you have to crank up the heat to get them that way. Perfume, usually cheaper ones, are chemically reproducing the odor produced by animal glands (civet cats for instance). Some of those "faked" odors are toxic. I don't think too many perfumers are using the natural substance anymore, making them kinda sketchy.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2015 11:16AM - edited Mar 15, 2015 11:21AM by leggo Hi catlady. If you're patient, the brown spots can be lightened with a combination of lemon juice, aloe vera, and sweet almond oil. It takes a long time, but does work if you hang in there. Rub lemon juice on the brown spot, follow with a light layer of aloe vera gel all over, then top off with sweet almond oil for some moisture. The lemon juice bleaches the brown spots, the aloe regenerates skin cells and the almond oil helps regenerate and provides moisture. Check the labels on the aloe vera....not all are as pure as they claim in the bold print. I like Lily Of The Desert brand "gelly". The sweet almond oil can be found at any health food store. Oh, and as a bonus it makes wrinkles less obvious too. P.S. Since you're light-skinned, concentrate the lemon juice on the brown spots only.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2014 10:51AM leggo wrote: I'm going to mention this because it's a potentially dangerous (even though I happen to be one of those crazy alties so often referred to). The reason the soap under the bed thing works for some is that may commercial soap contains magnesium sulfate. It's easily absorbed through the skin and even a tiny bit can ease the cramps.  If the soap works for you,  it's probably a sign that your electrolytes are out of balance,  more often than not, magnesium is the culprit. Usually not overly serious, and soap will do the trick, but if it gets too low, it's very dangerous. I thought it was important to mention that it could be a sign of a much bigger problem that should probably be checked out.  That's why you often see people getting chemo, getting a little bag of magnesium on the side.  Many chemos leach the magnesium out of your body.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2015 08:34PM - edited Feb 9, 2015 08:35PM by leggo I'm so very sorry. I went through the same thing with my mom. She would freak out just looking at the hospital bed that palliative care sent over and there was no way she was going to stay in it. I think part of it was fear, but mostly confusion. Too many unfamiliar things all at once for a confused mind to process. I just ended up having her lay down in a twin bed with a child railing and that seemed more familiar and she wasn't always trying to crawl out on her own. The other side was against the wall. There was this kids toy that made a lazer line over a certain area that would beep if it was crossed, and I put that on the floor by the open side of the bed. Also, I noticed if there was no white noise in the background, she got more agitated. It helped to have the tv on 24/7. She also struggled with breathing and for some reason, having a fan blowing calmed her. It didn't improve her breathing but it seemed to make her think it did. I don't know if any of this will be helpful to you, but I thought I'd throw it out there. I know how difficult it is to care for someone when they're confused and probably terrified. It's exhausting and heart-breaking. It was especially difficult to tell her that I would be ok if she wanted to let go of her worries. Things calmed down a lot after that. I knew I wouldn't be, but she really needed to hear it. Much love and hugs to you during this very difficult time.
Posts.Title: Update on Raro raro

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2015 01:37PM - edited Feb 10, 2015 01:39PM by leggo Hope you're hanging in there and mom's getting a little less anxious. Yesterday, I forgot to mention the most important thing that I learned while caring for my mom, other than the practical things. I had great difficulty getting her pain under control with the meds provided by palliative care. I really couldn't figure out why the oral meds were doing absolutely nothing except causing more pain. It wasn't until I spoke with her family doctor that everything fell in to place. If she's not eating, oral meds will just sit there in an empty stomach and burn like crazy until it's dispersed through the bloodstream, which just causes a vicious cycle of more pain. I'm the one who had to tell the palliative care nurse that I wanted her to have IV drugs only. She taught me how to run the IV pump at home and it made a huge difference. Once my mom's pain was controlled, she got more sleep. Thought I'd mention it because as great as hospice care is, sometimes they overlook the little things and just prescribe what they think would be the easiest for the care-taker to administer. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2014 12:26AM - edited Dec 22, 2014 12:29AM by leggo I think several years ago numerous studies were making the news about peanut butter promoting later breast health in tween girls. Never knew what to think about it at the time, nor did I care as I only had sons. Since then, however, there have been several more studies about aflatoxin in peanuts actually causing liver cancer. Apparently, this toxin grows in the fungus in a peanut shell. I think most of the danger can be avoided by refrigeration. Fungus generally doesn't grow in the cold. Unfortunately, that toxin is in all varieties of peanut butter, even organic. It has more to do with moist soil than pesticides because of the naturally soft shell of peanuts...great for harbouring fungus.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 01:02AM - edited Sep 10, 2013 01:07AM by leggo First, I hardly ever post in this forum, so excuse the intrusion, but I feel I have to interject to stop someone from drinking kerosene. Deb, regarding the kerosene, I wonder if you may be thinking of hydrazine sulfate. Hydrazine is a bi-product of rocket fuel. Some years ago, Dr. Gold had been on a talk show discussing this treatment. He was treating Bob Guccione's wife, Kathy. She had claimed that this "fuel", whose compounds could certainly misconstrued as kerosene, had shrunk her bc tumors. I honestly have no opinion on whether this worked or not, but you should know, that she later died from complications from surgery. It's still being debated whether or not the hydrazine sulfate is what killed her. Please, please, please do not ingest kerosene. It's vastly different from the hydrazine sulfate.
Posts.Title: Chemo no longer works - no more medical help????? DebGoudie HLB

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 04:55PM - edited Sep 11, 2013 05:41PM by leggo Hi Deb. Me again. I've been bothered by my last post to you. I fear I may have scared you. If you're anything like me, you research EVERYTHING that might help with this horrible disease. Hydrazine Sulfate is a legitimate drug (the rocket fuel bi-product). I remember researching it years ago when i first saw Kathy Keeton and Dr. Gold discussing it. I did discuss it with my doctor at that time and found out it could be somewhat effective in cancers that cause wasting. I kept it in my back brain pocket in case the time came that I may need it. In Canada, it is available by prescription. Anyway, I apologize for coming across as a "don't drink the kerosene" nut, which is probably something you already knew anyway. I just didn't want you burning out your esophagus. All this to say, that this particular "fuel" is an actual drug that has proven useful in some cases. I know I plan on using it if I have nothing else to lose.....but this is all something you can research on google and discuss with your doctor.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2015 11:49AM - edited May 22, 2015 12:15PM by leggo I agree with Shetland. Getting a second opinion shouldn't be an issue. Neither should switching oncs. However, when dealing with doctors you have to schmooze, keep it friendly. Bottom line, whatever doctor we see hold our life in their hands. You don't want to be labelled a problem patient. A tad manipulative, yes, but your life means way more to you than it does to him. They see people die everyday; they probably get jaded and angry too. A doctor is only human and has bad days like the rest of us. Stay on his good side. I've found that their body language and mannerisms mean way more than anything that comes out of their mouth. I would take that into account. edited to add: I just read your other post about the afinitor approval. Rather than speculating, I'd ask if he declined approval. He may have a good reason. It's a pretty harsh drug.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2014 08:29AM leggo wrote: We use reverse osmosis. We rent the system, no fuss, no hassle. Guy comes every six months to change the filter, maintain the units and check the water quality. From experience, it did not work being hooked up to the shower because there's just too many of us using the shower at the same time to wait for it to filter. They replace your drinking water tap with a smaller one for the system free of charge so your kitchen water is always on demand. If you happen to rent your water heater and softener from the same company, they often give you a deal on the osmosis systems. No water from the earth's toilet has touched my lips since 2006 unless it's been filtered. Worth every penny. The difference in the look and smell is amazing.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2015 04:18PM leggo wrote: I guess what we have to define is what "healed" means. Do I believe that cancer will just go away with alternatives therapies? No. Do I think you can drastically extend your life and the quality thereof with alternatives treatments? Absolutely. I had a tumor on my adrenal gland. There wasn't a doctor around that would remove it. I was seriously ill from this tumor. I HAD to go to Mexico to have it removed on my own dime. Without it being said, I just knew, that doctors here thought it wouldn't make any difference with my advanced disease. Screw 'em...I found my own way. Also, the story about the women in the video with (can't remember, was it lung, bone and brain who has survived all these years? Don't know, I quit watching) without conventional treatment, if she's saying she's cancer-free, I doubt it. If she says she's living well with the disease, not only do I think it's possible, I've survived since 2009 without conventional treatment. I'm not cancer-free by any means, but I'm still alive thanks to off-label drugs and alternatives to keep my immune system in top working order. I think each situation or story has to be taken with a grain of salt, but I do know that if there's a will there's a way to live beyond doctors' expectations. I think it all comes down to those who feel they have nothing to lose, try anything, and those who think chemo and radiation are the gold standard. I know answering that question comes easier to some than others. Relying strictly on conventional treatments never even crossed my mind so I can easily relate to both women. Not 100% sure though, that I buy either story, but I'm not going to judge, because I'm open to anything and everything, but I try to use common sense in the process. If you say you've been "cured" of your advanced cancer by "whatever", I tune out. If you say you've outlived the norm by "whatever", I'm all ears and quite comfortable being my own guinea pig.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 04:30PM - edited Jun 5, 2015 04:42PM by leggo Wiscgalsmile, I thought of a couple more things that I very much dislike about treatment. This first one applies simply to my province (in Canada), but there were several treatments I was on that my onc felt would be better done weekly and the first thing he asked me was "do you live in the city?", which I do, but it really bothered me that if I didn't, I wouldn't benefit. This was just him trying to make my life easier mind you, but I couldn't help feel sorry for others who lived rural. Looking back, none of these treatments were so specialized that they couldn't be adminstered through a rural medical facility with a crash cart. ( I suspect I'll be hearing otherwise from someone ) The other thing is there's no denying years of treatment takes its toll physically and emotionally. I really didn't want to hear "your hair will grow back, we can manage the side-effects, blah, blah. I know it's toxic...everyone does. Treatment shouldn't make you a shell. I am (was) one of the strongest people I know and I always took great pride in that. These treatments completely changed my personality ( as my family can attest to). Now I always feel vulnerable and out of control and I hate that feeling. I've still got that spirit, but the physical part is long gone and never came back. I miss the feeling that I could take on a n'er-do-well in the street. Now I know all I can do is run (or should I say quickly move away; running days are over), kwim? I constantly have to rationalize how far I'm willing to go (meaning stay alive) before I totally lose myself and undo all I taught my children leading by example. That's not what I'd hoped to teach them. I don't like them seeing me weak. There has to be a better way.....has to.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2014 02:20AM leggo wrote: Good for Dr. Jones. I know there are still doctors out there who do things for the right reasons. It's an admirable thing to question and bring it to public attention. I'd lay a bet though, that someone somewhere is going to shut him up and this will be the end of it. Not that I wasn't already skeptical of clinical trials, but this just makes me question their validity even more. Kind of heart-breaking to know that you laid your life on the line for the greater good in a clinical trial and never got information regarding the outcome. Outrageous really. Quite the quandry; ultra-powerful pharmaceutical companies keeping mum about failed results and privately-funded trials being forced to keep quiet about theirs. Maybe this good doctor will have the guts to blow the whistle. I'd love to see the lobbyists for big pharma go down in flames so the entire scientific community can get back to what really matters....saving lives. In a perfect world.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2015 09:05AM leggo wrote: No imaging for either of mine. First one was done when I was initially diagnosed to see if it had spread to spinal fluid, in which case there would be no surgery for a secondary cancer (that onc was a serious a-hole). It was clear. Second one was done after mets diagnosis for the same reason as yours. I couldn't walk. There were some cells, but not enough to cause the neuro issues. So yes, both were helpful to determine treatment, I guess. Pain is all relative, but I didn't find the procedure painful. I just curled up in the fetal position and the doctor felt around for where to put the needle. It was pressure (which some may interpret as pain), but it didn't bother me. Only laying there perfectly still for hours afterwards was painful on my hips and back. Good luck with yours. I hope they figure out what's causing your neurological issues and can do something about it.

Arrogant, lousy doctors who pretend to know everything about metastatic breast cancer (I have a particular one in mind), and the most difficult (annoying is not the right word) having the knowledge your children will have to be without a mother and through it all they have to watch this nightmare. If one or all of these would just go away, I'd be a happy camper.
